column1: question

17.25: Write chemical equations for the acid ionizations of each of the following weak acids (express these in terms of H₃O⁺). a. HOCN (cyanic acid) b. HF (hydrofluoric acid) c. HIO (hypoiodous acid) d. HCO₂H (formic acid)
column2: a. HOCN + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + OCN⁻ b. HF + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + F⁻ c. HIO + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + IO⁻ d. HCO₂H + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + HCO₂⁻

column1: 17.26: Write chemical equations for the acid ionizations of each of the following weak acids (express these in terms of H₃O⁺). a. HNO₂ (nitrous acid) b. HOCClH₂ (monochloroacetic acid) c. HCN (hydrocyanic acid) d. HCO₂H (formic acid)
column2: a. HNO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + NO₂⁻ b. HOCClH₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + OCClH₂⁻ c. HCN + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + CN⁻ d. HCO₂H + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + HCO₂⁻

column1: 17.30: Formic acid, HCHO₂, is used to make methyl formate (an artificial rum flavor). What is the pH of a 0.12 M solution of formic acid? What is the degree of ionization of HCHO₂ in this solution? See Table 17.1 for Kₐ.

17.31: C₆H₄NH₂COOH, para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), is used in some sunscreen agents. Calculate the concentrations of hydronium ion and para-aminobenzoate ion, C₆H₄NH₂COO⁻, in a 0.050 M solution of the acid. The value of Kₐ is 2.2 × 10⁻⁵.

17.32: Barbituric acid, HC₄H₃N₂O₃, is used to prepare various barbiturate drugs (used as sedatives). Calculate the concentrations of hydronium ion and barbiturate ion in a 0.20 M solution of the acid. The value of Kₐ is 9.8 × 10⁻⁵.
17.27: Acrylic acid, whose formula is HC₃H₃O₂ or CH₂=CHCOOH, is used in the manufacture of plastics. A 0.10 M aqueous solution of acrylic acid has a pH of 2.63. What is Kₐ for acrylic acid?
17.28: Heavy metal azides, which are salts of hydrazoic acid, HN₃, are used as explosive detonators. A solution of 0.20 M hydrazoic acid has a pH of 3.21. What is the Kₐ for hydrazoic acid?
17.29: Boric acid, B(OH)₃, is used as a mild antiseptic. What is the pH of a 0.025 M aqueous solution of boric acid?
17.37: What is the hydronium-ion concentration of a 2.00 M solution of 2,6-dinitrobenzoic acid, (NO₂)₂C₆H₃COOH, for which Kₐ = 7.94 × 10⁻²?
17.38: What is the hydronium-ion concentration of a 2.00 × 10⁻⁴ M solution of p-bromobenzoic acid, BrC₆H₄COOH, for which Kₐ = 1.00 × 10⁻⁴?

17.39: Phthalic acid, H₂C₈H₄O₄, is a diprotic acid used in the synthesis of phenolphthalein indicator. Kₐ₁ = 1.2 × 10⁻³ and Kₐ₂ = 3.9 × 10⁻⁶. (a) Calculate the hydronium-ion concentration of a 0.015 M solution. (b) What is the concentration of the C₈H₄O₄²⁻ ion in the solution?

17.40: Carbonic acid, H₂CO₃, can be found in a wide variety of body fluids (from dissolved CO₂). (a) Calculate the hydronium-ion concentration of a 5.45 × 10⁻⁴ M H₂CO₃ solution. (b) What is the concentration of CO₃²⁻?
17.41: Write the chemical equation for the base ionization of methylamine, CH₃NH₂. Write the K₆ expression for methylamine.
17.42: Write the chemical equation for the base ionization of aniline, C₆H₅NH₂. Write the K₆ expression for aniline.

17.43: Ethanolamine, HOC₂H₄NH₂, is a viscous liquid with an ammonialike odor; it is used to remove hydrogen sulfide from natural gas. A 0.15 M aqueous solution of ethanolamine has a pH of 11.34. What is K₆ for ethanolamine?
17.44: Trimethylamine, (CH₃)₃N, is a gas with a fishy, ammonialike odor. An aqueous solution that is 0.25 M trimethylamine has a pH of 11.63. What is K₆ for trimethylamine?
17.45: What is the concentration of hydroxide ion in a 0.065 M aqueous solution of methylamine, CH₃NH₂? What is the pH?
17.33: A solution of acetic acid, HC₂H₃O₂, on a laboratory shelf was of undetermined concentration. If the pH of the solution was found to be 2.68, what was the concentration of the acetic acid?

17.34: A chemist wanted to determine the concentration of a solution of lactic acid, HC₃H₅O₃. She found that the pH of the solution was 2.51. What was the concentration of the solution? The Kₐ of lactic acid is 1.4 × 10⁻⁴.
17.35: Hydrofluoric acid, HF, unlike hydrochloric acid, is a weak electrolyte. What is the hydronium-ion concentration and the pH of a 0.040 M aqueous solution of HF?

17.36: Chloroacetic acid, HC₂H₂ClO₂, has a greater acid strength than acetic acid, because the electronegative chlorine atom pulls electrons away from the O—H bond and thus weakens it. Calculate the hydronium-ion concentration and the pH of a 0.015 M solution of chloroacetic acid. Kₐ is 1.3 × 10⁻³.
17.49: Write the equation for the acid ionization of the Zn(NH₃)₄²⁺ ion.
17.50: Write the equation for the acid ionization of the Cu(H₂O)₆²⁺ ion.
17.51: For each of the following salts, indicate whether the aqueous solution will be acidic, basic, or neutral. a. Fe(NO₃)₃ b. Na₂CO₃ c. Ca(CN)₂
column2: a. Acidic b. Basic c. Basic

column1: 17.52: Note whether aqueous solutions of each of the following salts will be acidic, basic, or neutral. a. Na₂S b. Cu(NO₃)₂ c. KClO₄ d. CH₃NH₃Cl
column2: a. Basic b. Acidic c. Neutral d. Acidic

column1: 17.53: Decide whether solutions of the following salts are acidic, neutral, or basic. a. ammonium acetate b. anilinium acetate
17.54: Decide whether solutions of the following salts are acidic, neutral, or basic. a. ammonium cyanate b. pyridinium cyanate
17.55: Obtain (a) the K₆ value for NO₂⁻; (b) the Kₐ value for C₅H₅NH⁺ (pyridinium ion).
17.56: Obtain (a) the K₆ value for ClO⁻; (b) the Kₐ value for NH₃OH⁺ (hydroxylammonium ion).
17.57: What is the pH of a 0.025 M aqueous solution of sodium propionate, NaC₂H₅O₂? What is the concentration of propionic acid in the solution?
17.65: What is the pH of a solution that is 0.10 M CH₃NH₂ (methylamine) and 0.15 M CH₃NH₃Cl (methylammonium chloride)?
17.66: What is the pH of a solution that is 0.15 M C₂H₅NH₂ (ethylamine) and 0.10 M C₂H₅NH₃Br (ethylammonium bromide)?
17.67: A buffer is prepared by adding 45.0 mL of 0.15 M NaF to 35.0 mL of 0.10 M HF. What is the pH of the final solution?
17.68: A buffer is prepared by adding 115 mL of 0.30 M NH₃ to 145 mL of 0.15 M NH₄NO₃. What is the pH of the final solution?
17.69: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.10 M NH₃ and 0.10 M NH₄⁺? What is the pH if 12 mL of 0.20 M hydrochloric acid is added to 125 mL of buffer?

17.70: A buffer is prepared by mixing 525 mL of 0.50 M formic acid, HCHO₂, and 475 mL of 0.50 M sodium formate, NaCHO₂. Calculate the pH. What would be the pH of 85 mL of the buffer to which 8.5 mL of 0.15 M hydrochloric acid has been added?
17.71: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.15 M chloroacetic acid and 0.10 M sodium chloroacetate? Kₐ = 1.3 × 10⁻³.
17.72: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.10 M formic acid, HCHO₂, and 0.10 M sodium formate, NaCHO₂?
17.58: Calculate the OH⁻ concentration and pH of a 0.010 M aqueous solution of sodium cyanide, NaCN. Finally, obtain the hydronium-ion, CN⁻, and HCN concentrations.
17.59: Calculate the concentration of pyridine, C₅H₅N, in a solution that is 0.15 M pyridinium bromide, C₅H₅NHBr. What is the pH of the solution?
17.60: What is the pH of a 0.35 M solution of methylammonium chloride, CH₃NH₃Cl? What is the concentration of methylamine in the solution?
17.61: Calculate the degree of ionization of (a) 0.80 M HF (hydrofluoric acid); (b) the same solution that is also 0.10 M HCl.
17.62: Calculate the degree of ionization of (a) 0.20 M HCHO₂ (formic acid); (b) the same solution that is also 0.10 M HCl.
17.63: What is the pH of a solution that is 0.10 M KNO₂ and 0.15 M HNO₂ (nitrous acid)?
17.64: What is the pH of a solution that is 0.20 M KOCN and 0.10 M HOCN (cyanic acid)?
17.72: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.10 M propionic acid and 0.20 M sodium propionate?
17.73: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.15 M pyridine and 0.10 M pyridinium bromide?
17.74: What is the pH of a buffer solution that is 0.20 M methylamine and 0.15 M methylammonium chloride?
17.75: How many moles of sodium acetate must be added to 2.0 L of 0.10 M acetic acid to give a solution that has a pH equal to 5.00? Ignore the volume change due to the addition of sodium acetate.
17.76: How many moles of hydrofluoric acid, HF, must be added to 500.0 mL of 0.30 M sodium fluoride to give a buffer of pH 3.50? Ignore the volume change due to the addition of hydrofluoric acid.
17.77: What is the pH of a solution in which 15 mL of 0.10 M NaOH is added to 25 mL of 0.10 M HCl?
17.78: What is the pH of a solution in which 40 mL of 0.10 M NaOH is added to 25 mL of 0.10 M HCl?

17.79: A 1.24-g sample of benzoic acid was dissolved in water to give 50.0 mL of solution. This solution was titrated with 0.180 M NaOH. What was the pH of the solution when the equivalence point was reached?

17.80: A 0.400-g sample of propionic acid was dissolved in water to give 50.0 mL of solution. This solution was titrated with 0.150 M NaOH. What was the pH of the solution when the equivalence point was reached?
17.81: Find the pH of the solution obtained when 32 mL of 0.087 M ethylamine is titrated to the equivalence point with 0.15 M HCl.
17.82: What is the pH at the equivalence point when 22 mL of 0.20 M hydroxylamine is titrated with 0.15 M HCl?
17.83: Calculate the pH of a solution obtained by mixing 500.0 mL of 0.10 M NH₃ with 200.0 mL of 0.15 M HCl.
17.84: Calculate the pH of a solution obtained by mixing 35.0 mL of 0.15 M acetic acid with 25.0 mL of 0.10 M sodium acetate.
